headline: Missouri officials join push to put financial pressure on Russia
author: Kurt Erickson
sentences:
J.B. Pritzker on Monday asked the Illinois State Board of Investments, the Teachers’ Retirement System and the State Universities’ Retirement System “to explore the potential of divesting state pension assets from Russian-based companies and Russian assets.”

In the Missouri House, lawmakers are poised to consider a resolution sponsored by Rep. Mike Haffner, R-Pleasant Hill, calling on President Joe Biden to “reaffirm our country’s unwavering support for Ukraine’s freedom, sovereignty, and territorial integrity within its internationally recognized borders.”
The resolution says Biden should “immediately provide intelligence and send weapons and supplies to Ukraine, including anti-armor weapons, anti-aircraft weapons, and small arms, with no restrictions.”
“As a result of Russian President Vladimir Putin’s choices, Russia should immediately experience intense pressure on its economy and massive costs through isolation from the global financial system, global trade, and cutting-edge technology,” Haffner’s resolution notes.

On Tuesday, state Treasurer Scott Fitzpatrick, a Republican, requested an emergency meeting of the Missouri State Employees Retirement System board of trustees to prevent the future purchase of Russian securities and to discuss the strategic divestment of existing Russian holdings.

Another lawmaker, St, Charles County Republican Rep. Adam Schwadron filed legislation that would create a one-time, six-month tax holiday on motor fuel sales in the state in response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine and the expected ensuing rise in motor fuel prices.

In the Missouri Senate, Minority Leader John Rizzo, D-Independence, introduced legislation Tuesday to direct state and local governments, including their pension funds, to immediately divest from Russia and Russian businesses.
Fitzpatrick said the state-run pension system holds an estimated $13 million in Russian securities within funds worth over $1 billion as part of its investments into global emerging markets.
